article.title: A Fast Algorithm for the Coordinate-wise Minimum Distance Estimation

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1-(a) illustrates a part of the graph of function *f<sub>l</sub>* generated from 100 data points. What does this graph suggest about the function *f<sub>l</sub>*?
choices: *f<sub>l</sub>* is a continuous function with both local minima and maxima.
*f<sub>l</sub>* is a continuous piecewise linear function with multiple local minima.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1-(b) depicts the slopes of the line segments of *f<sub>l</sub>* over the intervals between the zeros. What is the significance of the points where the slope changes from negative to positive in Figure 1-(b)?
choices: They represent points of inflection of *f<sub>l</sub>*.
They represent points of discontinuity of *f<sub>l</sub>*.
They represent potential locations of the global minimum of *f<sub>l</sub>*.
They represent points where the second derivative of *f<sub>l</sub>* equals zero.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (2.1) represents the simplified distance function *L(b)* for the case where *H(x) = x*. What is the computational complexity of calculating *L(b)* for a fixed *b* using this formula?

Formula (2.5) expresses the selection of  *b<sub>l</sub><sup>(t+1)</sup>*, the updated value of the *l*-th element of the parameter vector in the (t+1)-th iteration. What does the set *E<sub>l</sub>* represent in this formula?
choices: The set of all zeros of the function *f<sub>l</sub>*.
The set of all points where *f<sub>l</sub>* attains a local minimum.
The set of midpoints of intervals where the slope of *f<sub>l</sub>* changes from negative to positive.
The set of all points where the derivative of *f<sub>l</sub>* equals zero.
